chapter.htmlHeader: When should I suspect malaria?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Suspect malaria in anyone who has returned from, or previously visited an area endemic for malaria, who is unwell or has a fever or history of fever, regardless of malaria chemoprophylaxisis — specific country information can be found on the TravelHealthPro website http://travelhealthpro.org.uk/.
    • Almost all cases of P. falciparum malaria present within 6 months of exposure and most within 2 to 3 months.
    • Infection with other malaria species, such as P. ovale and P. vivax may present months or years after exposure due to reactivation of hypnozoites (a dormant liver stage).
    • Presentation may be delayed in people who have taken chemoprophylaxis.
    • Most missed cases of malaria are wrongly diagnosed as non-specific viral infections, influenza, gastroenteritis and hepatitis.
  • Clinical features of malaria include:
    • Fever (often 39°C or higher), sweats and/or chills — absence of fever should not remove the suspicion of malaria.
    • Headache.
    • General malaise, lethargy and fatigue — somnolence is more common in children than adults.
    • Anorexia, gastrointestinal disturbance (such as nausea, abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhoea) and jaundice.
    • Poor feeding in children.
    • Myalgia and arthralgia.
    • Sore throat, cough, lower respiratory tract symptoms and respiratory distress.
    • Confusion.
  • Features of severe or complicated malaria in adults include:
    • Cerebral malaria — impaired conscious level (Glasgow coma score less than 11) or seizures.
    • Renal impairment (may present with oliguria).
    • Acidosis (may present with acidotic breathing).
    • Hypoglycaemia (<2.2 mmol/l) — common in pregnant women.
    • Respiratory distress which may be due to pulmonary oedema or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) — common in pregnant women.
    • Severe anaemia (may present with pallor).
    • Spontaneous bleeding/disseminated intravascular coagulation.
    • Shock (BP <90/60 mmHg).
    • Sepsis — more common in pregnant women.
    • Haemoglobinuria — falciparum can cause severe haemolysis with dark red urine (‘blackwater fever’).
    • Parasitaemia >10%.
  • Features of severe or complicated malaria in children include:
    • Cerebral malaria — impaired conscious level (Glasgow coma score less than 11 or Blantyre coma score less than 3), seizures, altered respiration and posturing (decorticate or decerebrate).
    • Severe anaemia (may present with pallor).
    • Respiratory distress or acidosis (may present with acidotic breathing).
    • Hypoglycaemia (2.2 mmol/l).
    • Prostration (inability to stand or sit).
    • Parasitaemia >2% red blood cells parasitized.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on when to suspect malaria are based on the clinical guidelines The diagnosis and treatment of malaria in pregnancy. Green-top guideline [RCOG, 2010], Management of imported malaria in Europe [ESCMID, 2012], Canadian recommendations for the prevention and treatment of malaria [PHAC, 2014], Guidelines for malaria prevention in travellers from the UK 2015 [PHE, 2015], Guidelines for the treatment of malaria [WHO, 2015] and the UK malaria treatment guidelines 2016 [Lalloo et al, 2016] and expert opinion in a review article [Feder, 2013].

Suspect malaria in all returning travellers who are unwell, have a fever or history of fever

  • A high degree of suspicion is needed in returning travellers with non-specific symptoms — misdiagnosis and delay of treatment are the most common reasons cited for death from malaria in Europe and the USA [RCOG, 2010; ESCMID, 2012].
  • A retrospective observational study of malaria-related deaths in the UK (n = 191) between 1987 and 2006 found case fatality to be inversely related to malaria incidence and suggested that malaria is more easily missed if clinicians are unused to seeing it [Checkley, 2012].
  • A retrospective study of malaria in Sheffield between 2000 and 2005 (n = 39) found that eight people presenting to healthcare professionals with malaria symptoms were not immediately referred for diagnosis or treatment suggesting that malaria was not considered in the initial differential [Green, 2009].

Clinical features of malaria are non-specific

  • Malaria in children (and sometimes in adults) can present with non-specific or misleading symptoms — a high degree of suspicion is needed [Lalloo et al, 2016].
  • Most missed malaria infections are incorrectly diagnosed as non-specific viral infections, influenza, gastroenteritis or hepatitis [Lalloo et al, 2016].

Absence of fever does not rule out malaria

  • Fever is not always present in malaria — absence of fever should not remove the suspicion of malaria in an ill person [Lalloo et al, 2016].
  • A study of 482 cases of malaria diagnosed at two tropical disease centres in the United States found that most cases had a history of fever, but only half were found to be febrile at presentation [Svenson, 1995].
  • People with paroxysms of fever may have a normal temperature between fevers and feel relatively well [ESCMID, 2012].
